channel.title: Run, Rich, Run!
channel.description: A running dairy, possibly with occassional rants and/or race pics.

item.title: How I came to be a Christian
item.description:
Growing up I remember the few times I went to church with my family. I remember spending a lot of time in the service trying to find the next hymn in the hymn book, wondering when to stand up, when to sit down, when to kneel. But I don't remember any of the sermons. Certainly church was somewhere you went for weddings or funerals, not a part of your life. As for Jesus: "Jesus was a Capricorn..." to quote a nonsense song.

At the end of my 'O' level year of high school, when I was 16, a teacher gave all her students bookmarks with a Bible verse on one side and a hand-written note on the other. I thought that a bookmark with a Bible verse on it should go in a Bible, so I got hold of a Gideon's King James Version.

Throughout university I was friends with a few people in the UCCF Christian Union group, and occasionally spoke to them, looking for a good debate. While at university I also met and became good friends with a girl, Vaniah, whose Christianity was the biggest part of her life.

In 1998, Vaniah moved to London and when I moved here in 2002 she was attending St Helens and invited me to come along, which I did -- a few time. But remained solidly resistant to what I was hearing. I did have lots of debates although these were less fun than I remember from uni because I didn't have the confidence in my position that most of the people I was talking to did in their position defending and explaining the Gospel. I didn't come to church very often and stopped completely because I couldn't answer the questions and didn't want to change my life -- I thought I was good enough without Jesus in charge.

Four years after that I met Heather on a sailing trip and though we were interested in each other she told me that she couldn't be in a relationship with me because I was not a Christian. I started coming to St Helens again, listening to the Gospel and getting into discussions where I couldn't defend my resistance to Jesus. I went to a Christianity Explored course and really started wresting with my philosophy that there was no need to ask big questions because there were no clear answers.

Mark's gospel account of the life of Jesus certainly had big questions such as Jesus asking Peter "Who do you say that I am?" - and it has big clear answers about what Jesus came to do. More than that, I was convinced of the historic truth of the Gospel and the terrifying prospect of living and dying as an enemy of God. On the 19th December 2006 I put my faith in Jesus Christ and asked him to help me live for him.

Changes since then?
  • How I spend my money - started giving to the church.
  • Spending more time with people.  I am quite happy on my own or hanging out with Heather, but I know that I need my church family and I can serve them.
  • Married to Heather!
  • I still struggle, still fight temptation to do my own thing.
So, what questions do you have that you don't know the answer to?
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Two hour canal run, 13.6 miles
item.description:
In preparation for the London marathon, I'm starting to think in miles instead of kilometers. Did a long run yesterday, focussed on time instead of distance. Ran out along the Grand Union Canal until I had run for exactly 1 hour, then turned around and ran back. Total run time, 2 hours, 1 minute, 44 seconds, so pretty happy that I wasn't significantly slower on the way back. Feeling tired and slightly sore, but not injured, so twas a good run. Hope to continue building time and distance so should be on target for 26th of April

Route at http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2660802
Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 21.8km
Time: 2:01:44
Pace: 5:35 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: There and back again
item.description:
Ran into work this morning, 6 miles, then back again this evening. Route at
http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2647397
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Twice round Hyde Park
item.description:
Early morning, roll out of bed and straight out the door. Down Abbey Gardens / Lisson Grove, then cut over to Edgeware Road and down to Marble Arch. Entered Hyde Park via Speakers Corner and stayed on the outer path around Hyde Park and Kensington Gardens. Back to Speakers Corner and around again for lap 2. Shorter lap this time, just around Hyde Park, not Kensington Gardens as well, cutting through on The Ring / Exhibition Road / West Carriage Drive, then back to Marble Arch and back home along Edgeware Road and Hamilton Terrace.

Running was dead slow, just adding distance, and very happy with that. Also had a bit of a detour on the way back (not shown on the route map or counted in the distance). Stopped to help out a guy in a wheelchair with a flat battery. Pushed him from Edgware Road, round the corner on to Oxford St and left him outside the KFC near Marble Arch station.

Have been listening to "The Privileges of Partnership" talk series on Philippians while I run (http://sthelens.audiop.org.uk/search/series/1911), and nearly finished it on this run. Running while listening to a talk seems to work really well, as long as there isn't too much traffic noise.

Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2635572
Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 17.8km
Time: 2:03:46
Pace: 6:57 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Saturday morning A-loop 13.5km
item.description:
Didn't feel like much of a run today, but my lovely wife encouraged me to go out. For the first 10 minutes I struggled and felt like heading back, but after that I started to enjoy myself. In the end, did 13.5km. Up Abbey Road until it turned into West End Lane, past West Hampstead, then on to the A41 to the A406, along to the A5 and back down past Cricklewood and Kilburn to home.

All on road, with a lot of car noise and fumes, and a bit of foot traffic at Kilburn High Street. Even so, easy run as I didn't have to think too hard and could just zone out and plod happily.

http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2527629

Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 13.5km
Time: 1:11:54
Pace: 5:20 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Work to home - 9.5km
item.description: Route at http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2494892
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Home, round Hyde Park and back home - 13.4 km
item.description:
Went out without starting my stopwatch, so time and speed for this run is an estimate. Felt like a good run, easy pace the whole way. Minor soreness in my right knee, but nothing work mentioning really, and soreness has gone completely now that I've finished and stretched. Think this is a good training run for this point in my build-up to the London Marathon on 26th April - 15 weeks away. Want to start adding serious distance soon and get my weekly training run up to half-marathon and beyond.

Route at http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2483201

Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 13.4km
Time: 1:15:00 approx
Pace: 5:36 min/km approx
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Regent's Park loop - 8.2km
item.description:
Routine trot round Regent's Park, just to make sure I haven't broken anything after yesterday's hill work. Tried to maintain a smooth pace, but not pushing for speed. Cold and dark out there, so this was hopefully useful for mental toughening as much as for fitness - got to build up the bloody-mindedness!

Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 8.2km
Time: 41:52
Pace: 5:06 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: New shoes, old route
item.description:
Heather and I both bought new running shoes today, and I went for a run this evening to test mine out. I did a loop of Hampstead Heath, similar to this route with a slight detour at the Royal Free Hospital, where I missed the turn on to Pond Road, and ended up going up into Hampstead Village for a second time and then home down the full length of Fitzjohn Avenue. Good hill work and good pace, significantly faster than previously.

Route at http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=2467015


Terrain: hilly on road
Distance: 12.5km
Time: 79 minutes
Pace: 6:19 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Runner number 7124
item.description:
All last week I have been getting emails from charities I registered with, so it wasn't a surprise when I came home yesterday and found an envelope from The Flora London Marathon addressed to me.

I'M IN!! On my third entry into the ballot, I have an accepted place in the London Marathon. God willing, on the 26th of April 2009, I will be running the 42,195 metres around the streets of London.

I'm feeling very emotional about this, more and more as I think about it. I'm scared, unhappy about the effort and training required, and at the same time, incredibly excited. The more I think about it, the more excited I am about the training, the improvement in fitness I will get as I train, and of course, excited about race day itself.

I've spectated the London Marathon a few times and get goosebumps even now, thinking about it. The energy and sense of passion you get from the runners is phenomenal, even when you can see the tiredness and pain. Bring it on!

I'm not required to collect anything for charity, since I was accepted in the ballot, but I've decided to fundraise for the Bowel Cancer UK charity anyway, so if you are reading this, please make a donation at http://www.justgiving.com/richardneish

More soon, once I've drafted a training schedule. The initial plan is lunchtime runs two or three days a week, then a long run on the weekend, building in time and distance as I get into shape.

Richard
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Hampstead Heath Loop - 12.5 km
item.description:
Way back in the end of July, I talked about some hill work. Well, three and a half months later, I finally did it!

From home, up Finchley Road to Swiss Cottage, then up (very up) Fitzjohn's Avenue to Hampstead Village, along the top of Hampstead Heath via Spaniard's Road to the Spaniard's Inn, then along Hampstead Lane, past Kenwood House to Highgate Village. Down the (very posh) West Highgate Hill to the bottom of the Heath, path the bathing ponds and the Parliment Hill fields.

At the bottom of the Heath, I turned right on Gordon House Road, past Gospel Oak train station, then continuing straight on Mansfield Road and Fleet Road. Turned left at the Roayl Free Hospital and uphill on Pond Street. Straight across at Rosslyn Hill to Lyndhurst Road (still uphill!) and then finally back to Fitzjohn's Avenue, down to Swiss Cottage and home.

All this took roughly 90 minutes, which sounds very slow, but it was early in the morning, coldish, uphill. I also haven't run at all for ages, and was very happy to take things slow and sightsee. There's certainly lots to see on this route!

Full route at http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1186070

Terrain: hilly on road
Distance: 12.5km
Time: 90 minutes (approx)
Pace: 7:24 min/km (approx)
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Slightly longer work loop - 6.7km
item.description:
Over Tower Bridge instead of Southwark, then southbank to Blackfriars and back to the gym as usual. This route is 6.7km as opposed to the normal 5km route.

http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1382559

Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 6.7km
Time: 35:27
Pace: 5:17 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Regents park loop - 8.7km
item.description:
From home, via Abercorn Place to Abbey Road, down to St John's Wood Road, along to Park Road, then in to Regent's Park and once around the Outer Circle anti-clockwise, then home by the same route as on the way out.

I tried to make this a fast run, and am reasonably happy with my pace. Slightly slow at around 6-7km but overall felt faster than my normal training pace. Good time and distance for a light training run.

Terrain: flat on road
Distance: 8.7km
Time: 42:35 (TBC)
Pace: 4:53 min/km

http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1368689 (Abbey Gardens to Regent's Park)
http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1368692 (Regent's Park Outer Circle, anti-clockwise)
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Robin Hood half-marathon 1:50:04
item.description:
Very happy with Robin Hood half-Marathon results on 16/09/2007. Started fast, with Gordon, but he sped off and I settled down to solid 8:20-8:30 minutes per mile (approx 5:11-5:17 minutes per km), fading a bit towards the end. I really want to put in the long run training to be able to sustain this kind of aggressive pace over a marathon distance.

I took one 3-dose energy gel with me and fed at 3, 6 and 9 miles. Basically I took a mouthful of energy gel 100m before the water stop, then washed it down with two to three mouthfuls of water. Worked well, although I felt slightly nauseous running and eating.

Terrain: undulating
Distance: 21.1km
Time: 1:50:04
Pace: 5:13 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Work to home without the wrong turns

http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1306347

item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: 5km lunchtime run - solo
item.description:
The usual route. Gordon didn't join me today, busy I assume. Legs were v. tired and soles of feet sore. Used the heart-rate monitor to see when I was being lazy and push harder, but this was not a fun run. At least, I don't feel like I have any injuries.

Slightly faster than the last few times as well, although not quite as fast as my best time for this route.

Terrain: flat
Distance: 5km
Time: 26:16
Pace: 5:15 min/km
Avg heartrate: 171 bpm
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: 5km lunchtime run
item.description:
The usual route from work. Gordon joined me and we took it slow and easy, chatting along the way. Gordon's knee is hurting, indicating a possible injury that will cause him trouble in the Nottingham Half-marathon in 10 days time.

Terrain: flat
Distance: 5km
Time: 27:38
Pace: 5:32 min/km
Avg heartrate: 176 bpm
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Work to home - 10.6km
item.description:
Tube strike today, so ran home from Bishopsgate to St John's Wood, via Regent's Canal. Haven't done this route before, so had a few wrong turns around Angel before linking up with the canal, but overall very smooth. Will definitely do again.

Haven't done any activity for ages, so took it slow and easy, stopping to stretch hamstrings at the start of the run, then sticking to slow and easy pace. Minor chafing issues, but overall very pleased with this.

Nottingham half-marathon in less than two weeks, and I haven't done any long runs, so that will be messy, but if I stick to this slow, easy pace, I should get round injury-free. No idea what that time will look line...

Watch this space.

Distance: 10.6km
Time: 1:01:27
Pace: 5'48" per km
Terrain: flat on roads and canal towpath
Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1286414
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Hill work?
item.description:
The canal route I did yesterday is great, and I'm very pleased with my time, etc. But. I think I need to add some hill work. Not many hills on the canal, apart from the little blips around locks. I've looked at gmaps-pedometer and come up with this route:

http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1186070

The distance is 12.5km which is an increment over yesterday's canal run, so I would be adding distance and hills! :-(

Worth a thought...
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Home canal route: 11.7km in 1:01:18
item.description:
http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1184598

Route: Abbey Gardens to Violet Hill, to Hamilton Terrace, to St John's Wood Road, to Warwick Avenue, to Blomfield Road, across the bridge, then on to the westbound canal path on the south side. Along the canal path for ages, then back

item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: 5km in 25:37
item.description:
Same 5km loop as the last time, nearly a minute faster. I had my heartrate monitor on, so was able to monitor my effort as I pushed a little harder. Heartrate was slightly higher than expected, about 180-185 bpm. Legs felt pretty heavy the whole way round, so I don't think my fitness is where I want it to be yet - there's a shocker!

Terrain: flat
Distance: 5km
Time: 25:37
Pace: 5:07 min/km
Avg heartrate: 177 bpm
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Work run - 5km loop
item.description:
This is the 5km loop I've done a few times during lunch. From the gym on New Broad Street, via the rear of the Royal Exchange, and lots of little alleyways to Southwark Bridge, across the river, then along the south bank to Blackfriars Bridge, back over to the north bank path, then back home.

Terrain: flat
Distance: 5km
Time: 26:34
Pace: 5:19 min/km

http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1318115
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Home, to Regents Park, round the Outer Circle, then home
item.description:
http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1162534

Route: Abbey Gardens to Abbey Road, to Circus Road, to Wellington Road, to Hanover Gate into Regents Park, around the Outer Circle (along the road) anti-clockwise, two laps around the running track at the north side of the park, back out through the Hanover Gate and back to Abbey Gardens.

Terrain: flat, sidewalk or road
Time: 49:12
Distance: 8.9km
Pace: ~ 5:33 min/km
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Canal run from St John's Wood
item.description:
http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=1156309

It's been ages, since I've done any runs, and even longer since I've written anything here about my runs - but I have been busy...

Anyway, here's the latest training run, along streets to Little Venice, then westward along the canal. 40 minutes total, 7.4km, basically flat on canal paths and roads.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Richard Neish)

item.title: Heather's house to my flat, with extra distance around Hyde Park
